descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Lucious Harris hit a go-ahead layup with 46 seconds to play and the New Jersey Nets rallied from a 23-point deficit in the second half to defeat the Charlotte Hornets 95-93 on Sunday.
article.headline: Hornets held to only 11 points in fourth

images.name: Kidd_Jason 020224 inline
images.caption: New Jersey's Jason Kidd, right, beats Charlotte's Jamal Mashburn to a loose ball. Kidd finished with 21 points in the Nets' big comeback.

article.linkText: Nets rally from 23 down to nip Hornets
article.story:
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) -- The Charlotte Hornets gave everything away on Sunday, first a 23-point second-half lead and then a last-second chance to tie because 12-year veteran Elden Campbell forgot the score. Campbell failed to take a 6- to 7-foot shot after grabbing a rebound with about 1 second to play Sunday, allowing the New Jersey Nets to post a 95-93 victory in their biggest comeback of the season. "It was just a mental mistake on my part, thinking we needed a 3," said Campbell, whose face dropped at the final horn when teammate Jamal Mashburn walked up to him and pointed out his gaffe. "That's why when I caught the ball under the hoop and threw it back out. I was right there wide open for a layup and I just blew it." The Nets had a lot more than three points to think about in rallying for their sixth straight win. They cut a 23-point third quarter deficit to 14 entering the final quarter and they won by outscoring Charlotte 27-11 in the fourth quarter behind the play of Kidd, Lucious Harris and rookie Richard Jefferson. Kidd had 21 points and 15 assists, Harris scored eight of his 17 points in the fourth quarter and Jefferson had two blocks and the assist on Harris' go-ahead layup with 46.4 seconds to play. "I think we were just sleepwalking out there in the first half, waiting for the real team to show up," Kidd said. "Charlotte is too talented of a team. We can't play like that. Defensively, we were soft in the first half. Once we got the game to our tempo, running, forcing turnovers, then we finally got going. It shows the true character of this team." The Hornets got their final chance to won their sixth straight road game because Kidd made only two of four free throws in the final 18.9 seconds, giving the Nets a 95-93 lead with 13.2 seconds to play. The Hornets called a timeout and set up a play inside for Campbell. When the play broke down, Baron Davis, who had 29 points, was forced to take a 3-point attempt from about 26 feet. While it was never close, Campbell got the rebound cleanly in the lane. Instead of going right back up, he turned and passed the ball back to Davis as the buzzer sounded. "That's the first time I've ever done that -- high school, college," Campbell said. "I always know what's going on with the clock situation. I don't what happened." Neither did Nets coach Byron Scott, who like Campbell attended Morningside High School in Inglewood, Calif. He didn't care though after the way the Eastern Conference leaders rallied. "We made a 360-degree turn in the second half and started to play like the team I've seen over the last four months," Scott said. Kenyon Martin shook off ankle injury early in the third to add 13 for New Jersey, which is 23-6 at home. After hitting 55 percent of their shots in the first three quarters, the Hornets were horrible down the stretch. They shot 5-of-21 from the field and had five turnovers. "They played better than us in the second half, that's all I have to say," Hornets coach Paul Silas said. After George Lynch hit a jumper to give Charlotte an 84-68 lead, the Nets responded with a 21-2 spurt to take an 89-86 lead on reverse layup by Kidd with 2:07 to go. A three-point play and a layup by Davis put Charlotte ahead 91-89 with 2:24 to go. After Davis failed to convert a three-point play on the second layup, Aaron Williams tied it with a short shot with 2:07 to go. After several scoreless possessions, Jefferson fed Harris for his go-ahead layup. Kidd then added a couple of free throws, setting the stage for Campbell's blunder. Jamal Mashburn had 24 points for Charlotte in his best game since returning from a 42-game absence caused by an abdominal strain. The Hornets took control early with a 12-point first quarter run that featured six points by P.J. Brown and four by Davis. Mashburn capped that spurt with reverse layup for a 26-16 lead. Still leading by eight early in the second quarter, Davis and Lynch scored five points apiece in a 19-7 run that ballooned the lead to 52-32 with 3:14 left in the second quarter.

Game notes
Martin left the floor for about three minutes after rolling his left ankle on the first basket of the second half. ... Charlotte is only one of two NBA teams with a better road record (16-12) than at home (11-16). Miami is the other with a 12-16 road mark and a 10-15 record at home. ... The Nets are 3-0 vs. Hornets this season. ... Coming in, Davis was averaging 25.8 points in his last six games.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
